channel.title: DIR-815 on IoT Hack Labs
channel.description: Recent content in DIR-815 on IoT Hack Labs

item.title: Discovery
item.description: Run nmap against the target. The -Pn flag is used to scan ports even though nmap is not receiving a ping response from the device. nmap 172.21.0.23 -Pn You should see that only port 8080 is shown as open. Host discovery disabled (-Pn). All addresses will be marked 'up' and scan times will be slower. Starting Nmap 7.91 ( https://nmap.org ) at 2021-10-19 13:20 MDT Nmap scan report for 172.21.0.23 Host is up (0.

item.title: Brute Force Login
item.description: We can see if the login has been configured with weak credentials by using a brute force attack with a password list. There are several tools to do this. We will use a Metasploit. Metasploit Metasploit is an exploitation framework that will allow us to select a target and run different modules. We will use a module created to automate login attempts against some dlink routers. In a terminal, open up Metasploit.

item.title: Command Injection
item.description: The DIR 815 is vulnerable to command injection once authenticated. Make sure you found the password from the previous steps. Open Burpsuite For this step, we will use Burpsuite. Click the Kali drop down in the top left corner and search for Burp. Open Burp. This may take a few seconds. Click Next Click Start Burp Navigate to “Proxy” > “Intercept” tab and turn off Intercept. Open the Burpsuite Browser In Burpsuite, click on the open Browser button.
